title: Filed Adversary Proceeding as Creditor against my ex-spouse (debtor). We settled. Signed Agreement. How do I close the case?
question: My ex-spouse filed Chapter 7 Bankruptcy. He listed me as a creditor. Why? I have no idea he doesn't owe me anything. However, per our divorce decree I am entitled to 1/2 of his CalPERS.
answers: I would prepare a consent order for both of you to sign reflecting the settlement agreement...specifically stating that the debt is not discharged pursuant to 523a(5) and (15) rather than dismissing the case...I always feel better with a signed final order. Once the consent order is entered the court will close the case as settled rather than dismissing it.

I agree with my colleagues. I would add that you should check the local rules to make sure you do all that is necessary. You can find those rules on your court's web site.

I hope this helps.
Respectfully,
Steven A. Leahy
www.chicagotaxteam.com

I agree with my colleague concerning the dismissal procedure. I believe before you bring your motion to dismiss, you should reduce your agreement to a formal stipulation and order, sign it and present it to the Court. I would not dismiss the case before this Court order is signed. Be sure to consult your own attorney to protect your legal rights.

File a Motion to Dismiss with the court. Be sure to use the adversary case number in the caption. If you can't get the motion filed at least a week before the date set for the hearing to to the hearing and just ask the judge to dismiss the adversary case and let him or her know that you have settled with the defendant. Judges love to have cases settled and off their calendars.
